At 20:16, Alice finds a valid proof of work before everyone else, and the animation shows Alice’s block being attached to the end of Bob’s blockchain. (Presumably, it is added only to Bob’s blockchain, and no-one else’s, since Alice wants it only to be added to his, for the reason explained at 19:55-20:11.) How does she ensure that only Bob and no-one else accepts her block? Just privately sending him a block would be suspicious, since there is supposed to be consensus about who has paid whom. In other words, is there a way to privately send a message to someone in such a way that it appears to be public? (The miners evidently do not know that Alice has sent Bob a block, for even after she sends it to him at 20:16 they keep working to find a valid proof of work for the block that is published publicly at 20:27.)

Crypto currencies are a very clever expression of technological thinking but they are not a "Currency" and do not behave as such,  They are a non tangible, highly volatile and risky asset, and im stretching the meaning of the word "Asset" to be kind.  They have no tangible or real world value because they cannot be used to make anything.  They are not a store of wealth because no store of wealth can have 40% of it's alleged value wiped out within a matter of days as Bitcoin did recently.  Bitcoin and other crypto's are nothing more than a contemporary digital Ponzi scheme.  The value of crypto relies wholly on the confidence that people have that they will eventually be able to sell it for more than than paid for it and for that to be possible it requires a constant flow of buyers coming in at the bottom.  If people ever lose confidence in Bitcoin and cryptos that will be the end of it and many late buyers will end up holding the bag.  It's a Con game.

So, let me check my understanding: the main reason to use bitcoin structure, where each block is linked to previous one, is to disallow other participants of cryptocurrency, who hold their own copy of the ledger, to skip some blocks (for example, Bob skips the block with transaction 'Bob pays Alice $10' to fool her). If Bob skips that block, he can't participate further in next transactions, as the majority of others have accepted that block and continue to build next transactions on that block, while Bob create a 'fork' of blockchain that nobody accepts.

But when you received a block with transaction, how do you know wether it is legit, that is, it is a real transaction with mutual aggrement and a fake one? Here's where proof of work comes into play: if we assume that the majority is honest, that single maliciuos user couldn't forge fake blocks as fast as the legit majority creates legit blocks, because he need to make proof of work. The majority simply has more computation power to outperform the malicious user. Hence, the strategy is to peak the blockchain fork with biggest lengths

One note: a more accurate word for a blockchain is a distributed system. Decentralized systems, logically, are chaotic, and have no central rules governing their behavior, which would, obviously, be terrible for a currency. Bitcoin is hyper-centralized, which is what makes it so hard to hack. The rules are very, very rigid, and anyone who tries to violate those central rules will get booted out of the system (which is also where hard forks come into play, as some folks want to changed the rules of Bitcoin, and had to split off and become a different currency).

The block chain methodology appears to have devised a way to ensure secure transactions; and people smarter people than me have likely answered most of the objections, I guess I remain skeptical. I base this on nothing more than human nature, greed, and the ability of people with personal motives to somehow work the system to their own benefit. For example, why couldn't a clever programmer just place 30 zeroes - followed by a random number set at the end of his block chain (after inserting his payoff), then replacate a large number of these pseudo-blocks and rapidly distribute them in quantity to an unsuspecting world? And, Bob's your uncle, and Bitcoin becomes another Magino Line to be circumvented.

Besides, is it possible some miners do not receive the broadcast?

The issue right now is no one can foresee where this space is heading. Metaverse is an obvious choice in purchasing land as it's backed by FB but when I bought my VR headset a lot of people didn't want to have any association with FB like having to create an account to access their VR profile. It's cool to find the technology and maths involved interesting, but it should be noted that cryptocurrency in practice is a hypercapitalist nightmare and active scam. People will talk about "turning $1,500 into $2,000,000" and use this pitch to aggressively recruit unwary people. Here's how the scam works:
-they spent $1,500USD of 'real' physical money on an equal amount of crypto
-they (probably) gambled it up to 2 million or artificially inflated the price of their assets through speculative hype
-they still have not made any $$$ from this, they have accumulated imaginary digital tokens that are worth absolutely nothing because you can't use crypto for anything EXCEPT other crypto projects
-they can only use this newly accumulated wealth by selling $2,000,000 worth of tokens to "bigger fools", aka the people they are telling HEY GUYS BUY CRYPTO YOU'LL GET SUPER RICH JUST LIKE ME I SWEAR BRO PLEASE

There are many other reasons why it's bad such as the environmental impact as well as a slew of socioeconomic issues, but it is functionally useless. Why do you think crypto nuts always talk about things in dollars instead of bitcoins or ethereum? Because they want you to believe that possessing "$2,000,000 worth" is the same as having $2,000,000. If nobody's left to buy, the bubble's going to pop.

I don't consider renting passive income unless you have professional property management. Most people who rent don't count their time and effort needed just to make a tiny return on their massive investment. For example, you invest $599,000 to buy a second home and rent it out for $3000 a month. Let assume you are cash flow positive on the property and you make $1000 a month or $12,000 a year. What would your annualized return be? 2 percent on the entire amount. Now, you can argue that your return is much higher since you only put down $120,000 on the property. However, you are on the hook for the full $600k regardless of what the future FMV of the house is. Furthermore, people assume that their home will always appreciate in value however, this is a false assumption you can make. In the best case, you will gain some capital appreciation thanks to the central bank increasing the money supply, however, if inflation heats up, you can see your property actually start to lose money in real terms. This is because there is an inverse relationship between housing and nominal interest rates. The central bank will attempt to slow down inflation with higher interest rates and curb lending. We haven't seen inflation in a big way but we can see all the massive stimulus money that the government is pumping turn into inflation while taxes will be hiked to pay for all the COVID spending, your best choice is to look into support@ Thespacehackers🎡com Its more profitable.

Prior to watching this I didn't really understand the link between mining and validating the transactions. Its quite interesting how the system can self-adjust to make sure that mining\validating is always profitable, and therefore even if there is a big crash in mining profitability it should just result in a slowdown of transactions until the system balances. I guess the issue is that there is a big problem if the coin is used for real large scale commerce\business that rely on guaranteed volume. If a large enough proportion of bitcoin transactions were for real vital goods and services, then a crash in mining profitability could drive he value to zero since the value would be much more tied to the amount of volume the system can handle. Lack of trust could continually inflate it, which would then continually make it harder to restore validation capacity. Volatility is an issue for real world business even if the overall trend is continually upwards.
If I am correct, then it would suggest that bitcoin will remain a speculation asset and a store of value rather than a replacement for sovereign currencies?

comment_by: Best regards to Nikto_miner👈 on telegram👈
comment_text: On cryptocurrencies, I want to emphasize two points.  First, while there are cryptocurrencies that do not appear to be securities, simply calling something a “currency” or a currency-based product does not mean that it is not a security.  Before launching a cryptocurrency or a product with its value tied to one or more cryptocurrencies, its promoters must either (1) be able to demonstrate that the currency or product is not a security or (2) comply with applicable registration and other requirements under our securities laws.  Second, brokers, dealers and other market participants that allow for payments in cryptocurrencies, allow customers to purchase cryptocurrencies on margin, or otherwise use cryptocurrencies to facilitate securities transactions should exercise particular caution, including ensuring that their cryptocurrency activities are not undermining their anti-money laundering and know-your-customer obligations.

I'm still confused by one point: If you can't spend crypto you don't have, and a transaction is broadcast to everyone at about the same time, then shouldn't everyone have a copy of that transaction by the time the recipient goes to make another transaction?

I got it:

Have every participant in the system ask everyone else for their copies of the ledger - or, for a hash of their copies of the ledger. If there is disagreement, then what the true ledger looks like gets put to a "vote" of sorts. If 75% of ledgers agree that you gave Alice $20, she gave Bob $30, and he then gave you $10, then THAT is what actually happened.

And some etymology. The verb "crypto" in ancient Greek (cryvo in modern Greek) means "to hide". So the term "cryptocurrency" in Greek is translated as "hidden currency", spreading fears among many Greeks of something secret and dangerous. Of course the term "crypto" does not refer to the currency itself but to the code behind it.

I understand the ledger idea that someone just settles up and pays the balance owing. But then they obviously pay with existing currency. The ledger units then just keep track of their exchanges in the interim. Then perhaps they buy ledger units in advance -- with existent currency -- to assure others they have available funds committed to settle up (?).

Then it all melts down. I don't see how the ledger units have any intrinsic value beyond the existent currency used to pay for them or to settle up.

A currency should ideally be designed to maintain its unit value -- as a unit of account -- and to not inflate or deflate. This crypto currency has no such intention. (Gold or silver coins are not 'money' -- and they too can go up or down in value depending on the market value (easily manipulated) of the mineral.

Accepting a 'ledger unit' or any unit of currency in exchange for actual goods and services is a 'loan' and involves lost opportunity cost. Is this being understood and acknowledged with crypto?

Our current money system is an ideal money system -- underneath the fraud that lays on top of it.

Commercial banks don't loan depositors money. When a dentist takes out a mortgage he is really just issued his own coupon for dental services. He has to honor these coupons on a strict schedule -- so many per month. So it's super simple and easy to see why those coupons -- now called dollars -- have intrinsic value.

People are totally ignorant of this and derisively call such money fiat -- ie just paper. There is fraud -- but not in the underlying system. We just need to remove the fraud.

The crux of the fraud is in this: when the dentist receives a house for his coupons from the public -- then honors his coupons, providing dental services to the public -- then who provides the loan? Now: who collects the interest?

The inflation and deflation in our current system is a product of the scam -- not of the true and logical money system operating underneath the scam.

This is a really easy to understand scam with a beautiful true 'simple and clear' money system operating underneath it -- and an easy situation to fix. The correct system is already largely in place.

The crypto concept is a device to bamboozle the public all over again with a much more convoluted scam -- that will be much more difficult for people to see through and fix.

(Money is also not 'backed' by gold. That story is a scam to make people believe something is loaned out of a vault -- when it isn't. Money is simply and logically backed by risk of default insurance paid for by the borrower. This is the ever so mysterious and deceptively named 'fractional reserve.')

What about deflation?
Will Bitcoin ever deflate? Because at some point the growing production, value, or GDP, whatever you want to call it... won't that global growth rate surpass the growth rate of new BTC 'lotto tickets' rolling out?
Or will Bitcoin tend to follow some other kind of standard.... another fiat currency, gold, anything? (That is, opposed to BTC itself being the standard for other currencies or other cryptos).
I guess deflation all depends on supply and demand...
I could definitely see a large supply drop-off in 10 years. People 'hoarding,' 'hedging,' even banks buying up supply and decreasing the float. It's interesting to see where this might go.

But the main question that I can't get over is:
Is crypto an asset, or a currency?

Because if it's a currency, what does it matter if I don't get on board early. As long the U.S. dollar doesn't collapse, or hyperinflate, it won't be like I'm missing out on anything, right? It would eventually stabilize.

But if it's an asset....
I can't really justify calling it an 'asset'. I mean it will always have that symbolic value of 'being the first crypto name everybody heard of,' but...
Crypto isn't creating value. It isn't providing goods or services to people in any way. (Or maybe it is... let me know how if that's the case, I don't want to argue, but just to learn. I guess the closest analogy it could draw to an asset would be real estate. But again, idk.)
And then the argument with that becomes... well even if it is an asset, I could invest in real estate as an asset instead, or land, commodities, art, classic cars... I mean I'd trust the value of those things in 10 years down the road before I trust crypto.
And you can get your hand in the cookie jar too by investing in companies like GOOG, AMZN, SQ all while getting exposure but at the same time too kind of off-loading the risk. (If you want to call it 'risk.' Maybe 'uncertainty' is better.)

So I guess the main point it... if it's a currency, I'll be fine as long the dollar doesn't go crazy, or I have assets that protect against the dollar going crazy... and on the other side, I'm much more secure investing in things I know 100% to actually be assets and having physical value as opposed to virtual value.

So. That's my take on it. Probably nobody listening, but typing that out helped sort my thoughts a little bit lol.

In physics, "work" (defined scientifically as a force applied thru a distance) is what you can do with energy, and both are measured in the same units.  And energy can be measured as kilowatts-hours of electricity, or equivalent barrels of oil, both critical commodities.  Compare with "Wampum", the intricately woven bead belts used by northeast Native Americans as currency. Though blockchain, and cryptocurrency as a result of it, are awesome by themselves, I believe we're already facing the result of a fundumental problem with it: completely meaningless computations. Or in other words - meaningless waste of resources. Not only electricity. We can totally count "computational power" of humanity as a separate resource, and it is also being wasted. To better understand what I mean, imagine there was a cryptocurrency based on the randomness of the smoke-particles after burning oil. In this case, we would start feverly burn all the oil we could get to just generate a currency. If I were alien and discovered Earth suddenly, I would certainly think hunams are not too clever to bother getting in contact with them. Cryptocurrency is good, but it's still a currecny which has only virtual value, like any money. So, why spend so much resources on just generating this currency. There must be other ways for it. Or, if we still take the proof-of-work concept, the work must not be just "burn more resources than others".

People just need to turn on their imagination. There are lots of examples of usefull work that could be done. If we still take compuations: there are a lot of scientific projects for distibuted computations where everybody can participate. There could even be a block-chain of scientific discoveries, where trust could be based on distributed council of scientists. Etc etc. Just some thought-efforts need to be done.

The example with oil above was not random, though still pretty demonstrative, I believe. Once upon a time, hunamity invented internal combustion engine. That was certainly a breakthrough. But is it worth mentioning why do civilized countries tend to switch to more optimal and ecological electric cars. Same is with the useless compuations. They are wasteful.

Bitcoin/Crypto is NOT a currency. Its a cryptographic commodity. Big error with the presentation to not explain that.
If you alter a balance sheet at minimum that has to adhere to database definition ACID atomicity, consistency, isolation and durability properties.
However a modern currency is O(1) to make changes to interlocked balance sheets. Blockchain in some degree of Big Oh n factorial.
Eg: if i want to transfer currency, or issue currency that's 'work' that is not intrinsic to the fundamental algorithm of the currency. You're only maintaining a database with the OPTION of degrees of security which may/may not be centralized or computationally complex.

Problem with bit-crypto's are they ARE centralized because you have to all agree on the rate of work to mine the block chain and the number of transactions to sign, and with which function SHA, PBKDF2, Argon2, BCryptSHA256 etc.

Good luck if you've invested millions in dedicated mining hardware and a non-elected central body that administers the block chain branches, changes the hash or rate of growth for mining the block chain.

Of course it worth pointing out from an energy efficiency point of view crypto currency is GAME OVER for the environment. Goodbye ice caps hello 4 degrees C global warming.

They are diluting the concept of Crypto Currency by having so many types. The bottom line is that all Cryto Currencies are on computers, cell phones or in electronic wallets, and they will all fail when an EMP hits or we have power outages. Even though Bitcoin is sitting at 55 thousand dollars each, when an power outage happens it might as well be forth a Kazillion for all the good it is going to do you. If you cannot reach your money it is actually at that point WORTHLESS. UNLESS YOU HAVE MONEY (or more rightly, currency) in your possession you don't have squat. Distributed Ledgers actually work, but are more suited to things that are not critical as is our cash.

There are now people who are using that Distributed Leger technology to become banks in their own right, loaning out money and charging whatever interest the market will bear, and calling it a personal financial transaction, so the banks or the government cannot force them to adhere to regulations and licensing as are brick and mortar banks. This is a very slippery slope as it comes very close to Usury and Shyloking which was made illegal many decades ago.

I think we all understand this better than we think, because we already use this system (except it involves the federal reserve, employers, banks, credit card companies, and PayPal, etc). Like I wanna buy something on Amazon, so my employer directly deposits money into my bank account then I use that money to pay my credit card bill, which covers may PayPal purchases, which sends money to Amazon, and Amazon sends money to the product seller. No one ever touched any cash. It was all done by sending one encrypted message from ledger, to ledger, to ledger. Awesome Video Grant but can I just add a little technicality here in an attempt to prevent confusion of a very confusing and badly misunderstood concept. A private key is never called a secret key, (although I do understand for the purpose of the video, it allows you to use different abbreviations) but a Private key and a Secret Key are totally different things, used for totally different operations and are always confused with each other.   PKI or Public Key Infrastructure, is a system that generates both a Private and Public set of keys, that are both born on the server (or lets say the receiving end), of the initial communication handshake, and is ONLY used to secure the communications channel at first then discarded.  A Private key can only decrypt and a Public key and only ever encrypt.  Public Keys and Private keys, go together ( and are generated together) to perform the encrypted or secret transport of another 3rd Key, called the secret key, that is totally born on the client end, (lets say the initiating end), across a now  secure communication channel, made possible by the PKI.  A secret key, is a totally separate key only used for the final encryption and decryption of the data or message, that is passed via the PKI, which is purely for the purpose of encryption and decryption of the actual data or message you wish to send.  It is amazing how many people even in the very technical IT world totally misunderstand this concept and in fact there are many Youtube videos that incorrectly state this, and I just want to make sure people understand how important this is, because this is at the heart of us feeling secure when we pass transaction back and forth. It is commonly thought the the PKI is doing the encrypting and decrypting of the data across the channel when it is not. This is only ever done by the Secret Key and the only point of the PkI pair is to get that secret key across the channel securely.  Hope this helps everyone's understanding more on this very murky subject.

This claim isn't exactly true. Obviously it's not the case for the hash functions people still use, but plenty of hash functions that people used to think were secure were later cracked. Worth noting that the common system for asymmetric encryption, RSA, CAN be cracked through methods other than bruteforce. While we haven't discovered a method that works for all cases (plenty for special cases though) AND can be implemented on ordinary hardware (quantum computers can crack any RSA message if their processor is significantly large), we also haven't proven that such a method doesn't exist. More over, if NP = P, which is an unsolved problem in mathematics, than any RSA message could be cracked with ordinary hardware. For those of you who think you're dumb because you didn't understand this video, trust me, you're not. I'm a computer science student and I can tell that if you aren't one, you're probably gonna have some trouble in understanding some basic parts of this video (no fault of the creator tho, this video's awesome!). A few pointers for you guys: A function here (i.e. a function in code) does essentially the same thing as a function in math. It takes some input (given in brackets) and works on it to give an output. Different functions have different types of outputs. So some functions return only True or False, while others return numbers/words, etc. Secondly, in case anyone here thinks that you could just use a very powerful machine to guess the secret key through brute force, just know that you can't. I mean, you can but it would take decades(if not more) for even the most powerful machines in the world to correctly guess the entire thing (If you're interested in this, I would recommend for you to check out Dan Brown's "Digital Fortress" just to obtain some idea about this approach). Also, this is pretty basic but just in case someone is wondering, everything here is given in 0's and 1's because those are the two digits that form every piece of data in a computer's memory. These are called bits (as in bits of data). Every single number, every alphabet in a computer's memory is formed using these digits (much like every building made using Lego is a product of a bunch of Lego blocks). Hell, even different colors have separate unique codes using 0 & 1 (primarily why the sRGB palette exists, because every color can be made using Red, Green & Blue (RGB), and so every color's code is formed through combinations of Red, Green & Blue's codes). If anyone has more questions, I'll try my best to answer them. After all, I'm still a student so I don't know all that much.

P.S.- In case someone thinks I'm trying to act smart or something, I'm not. I'm just trying to explain whatever I think needs explaining since most of the top comments are about people not being able to understand video. Hope this helps! :)

There is this concept of Kerckhoff's Principle: Which means your security algorithms and implementations should be designed such that it being transparent and revealed don't compromise your security unless the key to the original plaintext is found.

In fact, security in open-source software depend on this concept too (the more transparent ... the more it is logically/mathematically proven for your correctness in algorithm) ... and you have security experts able to audit and review if the algorithm implemented on your GitHub project for your application is secure.

Anyways, even after study fully the SHA256, you will still need to find the original plaintext, or you need to be a savant to find an inverse function to counter this function by literally able to put in SHA-1 hash as an input to calculate in reverse.

This is a very interesting video, I am studying some cryptography and didn't know bitcoin used so many things I had learned before. However this system has some issues, not from a computational/mathematic view but social:
-Once the reward is too little, the only way for miners to accept a transaction will be the fee. As it is really hard to get the hash function, unless there are very few miners, the fee will have to be huge, or there will be very few miners, something that weakens the system security
-If there is another currency, like the us dollar, cryptocurrencies will never be used for buying, just to speculate. However, it could work if there was only one cryptocurrency globally
-electricity consumption is a problem for mining, tanking into account the amount of computational effort that takes to find the hash function
-using your own computer for mining alone, can be very hard, as most likely you will never find a hash function. So, as we have seen, miners get together into a net to find a hash. That undermines the system security, as there are less miners, and someone could actually have really high percentage of computational power.
- if the cryptocurrencie is global (imagine there are no dollars and other common currencies) and there is a huge crisis, there is nothing that can be done to get the economy back, it would take a long time to recover and many would suffer

These are some of the problems I see. However, as I said, I think it is a great idea, and mathematically beautiful ❤️

As someone who works in banking and cyber security, I don't think I will ever buy a bitcoin. One of the first things you learn in security, is "assume a system is already compromised", this way you can minimize what other systems or information is vulnerable. Also, because something seems impossible now form a security standpoint... doesn't mean the capability won't ever be developed. They said RSA tokens would highly unlikely to ever be compromised, and yet, years ago, it happened.

Here is a scenario I foresee. China and Russia get pissed off at the USA (cause aren't they always :) So what do they do, they pull their resources, maybe with Iran, North Korea and Venezuela, and they start constructing a fraudulent blockchain. Combined, they could very well have more resources and could be successful in pulling some users coins, small at first, but just enough to keep it unnoticeable. No thanks, but I will take a heavily regulated banking system over block chain any day. This system assumes that there are no bad actors, but the real world has A LOT of bad actors.

This carefully explains the counting system. Now, ask yourself "What substance is being counted?" Once you have an answer to that, all you need to know is how much a unit of that substance is worth in dollars? Then, by knowing how many units of that substance have been counted constiutes the answer, you then know the value of Bitcoin in dollars.

Of course, if no substance is being counted, then the answer is always zero. If nothing of value has been counted, then there is no value in being able to count it.

If my understanding of PK/asymmetric cryptography is accurate (and bear in mind, I FINALLY managed to wrap my head around RSA just about a week ago), a signature generated using RSA would be some value that, when you decrypt the signature (using RSA's exponent-Modulo trapdoor, as I'll call it for lack of a better word currently in my vocabulary), you get back the hash of the message? is that accurate?

What interests me most about cryptography is that the entire system, and I don't just mean cryptocurrency, depends on one crucial assumption, one which you yourself acknowledged: that the cryptographic hashing algorithm really is as secure and hard to reverse as we believe it is. If someone manages to break it, I wonder where the most monetary damage will occur: cryptocurrencies dependent on that security (because you can instantly get a digest with however many zeros you desire), or somewhere else like SSL or password hashes? I suppose it would depend who discovers it first and whether and where they attack with it, but either way... It'd be quite the spectacle for anyone in the information sciences industry.
supposing someone would use this to attack a block chain, it would basically consist of them racing to put as many favorable transactions on the chain as possible before people start catching on that the currency is about to collapse, and to do it effectively would likely require some amount of moderation to avoid people realizing why someone is beating the best GPUs & ASICs in the network. If people catch on, the value of the currency they are trying to steal drops to basically nothing before they can exfiltrate their stolen coins by converting them to gold or something (to some unfortunate sucker that's now holding a bunch of stolen and soon to be worthless coins and a cryptographic signature that proves nothing)

note: I am aware that there are multiple hashing algorithms, some more secure (or seemingly so) than others. I'm talking about them in general and supposing ANY of them were to be broken while still in major use. I also reiterate that I am fairly new to cryptography, so if I'm exaggerating the threat in any way or misunderstanding something, please correct me!

The biggest problem with any of these schemes is that the work required to confirm a block gets exponentially harder; eventually, it will reach a point where it's no longer feasible to solve. While BTC may claim the work is set to be solvable in "10min", it's based on the total estimated processing of the entire network. But the network is not cooperative; everyone is hunting for a solution independently, so a huge amount of work is being repeated. (much of the network will try the same solutions.) This is highly wasteful. (it takes hours for an average miner to confirm a block. it takes massive mining farms to meet that 10min mark.)

So this question might be a little complex, but I've got a feeling that this might be a big hurdle that cryptocurrencies will have to face in the near future.

Every cryptocurrency relies heavily on high speed communication. Between constantly broadcasting, receiving, and checking data, there is a ton of information that needs to be synced between each user in order for the system, as a whole, to work. Right now we only have a few milliseconds of delay between users here on Earth. But, when we eventually do start to colonize the solar system, light delay is going to become a huge problem.

Interplanetary distances are so vast that even lightspeed communications will have a significant delay in travel time. Just one-way, direct communication between Earth and Mars takes 4.5 minutes at best, and 21 minutes at worst. For Saturn it would take between 1 hour, 6 minutes at best and over 1 hour, 32 minutes at worst. And all of this is without the added time of uploading and downloading the data, relaying it to repeaters elsewhere in the system to boost the signal, or sending any replies or conformations back in the other direction.

With such a massive delay in communications, computational work might not be enough to validate transactions; and a lot could change on everyone's personal ledgers while the data is still enroute. So, how are cryptocurrencies going to work at all on such a large scale?

I direct people to this video when they need to learn how cryptocurrency works.

I also direct people here who fear they are losing economically due to some sort of technology beyond their understanding. Most quickly understand the basic truth that since no actual human-meaningful value is being translated into cryptocurrency (mining doesn't produce anything humanity actually needs or wants), that it's unimportant in the long term and they can safely ignore cryptocurrency, which will eventually die off as the fad it is.

It actually drives it's own death. The increasing cost and inefficiency of using the system takes away things of real value (the cost that went into the mining work) which detracts from the overall economy. Eventually, if we were to proliferate crypto too much, it would have an overall detrimental effect and be abandoned (hopefully). Heat loss is real, folks.

In the past several years, the use and prevalence of virtual currency have increased exponentially. The proliferation of digital assets has changed the way goods and services are exchanged and has allowed for faster and cheaper transactions. But with this new technology comes the increased risk of fraudulent activity – especially tax fraud. Recently, the Internal Revenue Service (“IRS”) has made it abundantly clear through guidance, amendments to tax forms, and even warning letters to Americans suspected of tax fraud, that it is getting very serious about virtual currency tax compliance.


The IRS and the Department of Justice (the “DOJ”) appear to be poised to commence a flurry of enforcement actions against virtual currency tax fraud offenders. Likely to be entangled in these enforcement actions are virtual currency institutions and companies that regulators suspect facilitated their customers’ tax evasion. It is thus imperative for all entities in the virtual currency industry to ensure their compliance programs are equipped to detect and prevent the facilitation of virtual currency tax fraud.

Can someone help me ? I don't understand something ...

You say that the number of starting zeros to obtain as a proof of work changes periodically so it takes on average 10 min to find a new block. I don't understand: if you find how to get 1 zeros, 2 zeros, 3, 4 ... all the way to 30, well you can store it and just try these specific values for the next time, because once you found it, you don't have to find it again (I assume SHA256 is an injective function). And 2^30 attempts are easy to perform, so it will be easy for me to get the value that gives all those 30 first hash (1 zero, 2 zeros , ... 30 zeros) and store them in my personal dictionnary, and reuse them later.

You will ask me: why would you stop at 30 ? I don't stop at 30, it can be more, but it cannot go up to 256, which would make the proof of work actually impossible to achieve.

So my point is : Either the number of zero to obtain is too large so it's impossible to get the proof of work, or it is more reasonable, but then you can just store it, and for the next time you can just try everything you've stored previously. It would take you less than 256 attempts, which is instantaneous for a computer.

So why does it actually requires work, if there are only 256 possibilities (presumably way less because no one can calculate how to start with 200 zeros) ?

My hypothesis is that it doesnt have to start with zeros, it can be any sequence of 0 and 1. That I could understand. But that's not what I understood from the video :/

So basically, this crypto technology is just there to ensure that nobody gets ripped off without having to have a bank there to ensure it. If the trust for governments and their central banks go completely out the window, people are putting their bets on this de-centralized currency.
Very cool, but I would still bet on the already established currencies for the time being. This could very well be a good, safe store of value, if it truly is "un-hackable", but it will only go up in value if demand for it increases. The supply part of it is already established, which is reassuring, but It's the definition of speculation to buy it as an investment. It's sort of like a pyramid scheme where those that already own it can only make money if new people stream into it, and where the ROI decreases the higher the price. The technology can be used to create any number of new, equally secure digital currencies. The case for Bitcoin in that case is only that it's "already established" and popular as a currency which justifies its price, but why would you in that case abandon the dollar, peso or yen? You could say the same thing about those, and since they are already being turned into digital currencies with their own ledgers and keys, why would you swich over? What would be the purpose?
This is as far as I get in my reasoning. Am I missing something? Please help me understand why it's necessary to introduce these new currencies.

Good video, but gives a false sense of understanding how Bitcoin works. Yet there are still so many questions...
The Alice fools Bob example only makes sense if block size was 1 transaction. But it's far bigger. How does everyone agree on what transactions go into block before they start calculating it's hash? If they don't really agree, they will be calculating hash of nonsense for quite a while.

Since receiving a signed block is not exactly trustworthy until you get several more after that, how likely are forks that are kinda valid, but not exactly? Say A sent BTC to B, while X sent BTC to Z, and one block has a ton of transaction + A to B transaction, while another, all same transactions + X to Z transaction. Both blocks are technically valid, but they're different - because of "race" between A to B and X to Z transactions (who was first?).

What happens if Alice, instead of broadcasting, sends to specific nodes transactions like "Bob paid me 1 BTC", "Bob paid me 2 BTC", "Bob paid me 3 BTC" etc etc?

And a lot of questions like that remain.

This has to be the best explanation of how cryptocurrencies work.
I will just add one thing.

The video's mock ledger works because Alice and Bob and Charlie had all met before in order to exchange their respective public keys. You KNOW that this public key is Bob's, so if a signature is verified with this public key then the message had to be signed by Bob.

But online, we haven't all met before. If I read somewhere that Bob's public key is 10010, what guarantees me it's true, and it's not a hacker who put his own public key next to Bob's name to pass his fraudulent messages as Bob's? Online, there is no way to exchange public keys without having to trust a central authority like a root certificate authority.

In order to remain decentralised, Bitcoin doesn't use Alice or Bob as the sender or recipient of transactions, it uses bitcoin addresses... which ARE actually the public keys.
So you are only sending bitcoins to a public key, and not to a name. If "Address A" was listed as a recipient of 10 BTC in some block, then only the owner of the private key corresponding to Address A can sign a transaction to spend these 10 BTC, and you don’t have to know who that actually is.

This is why Bitcoin is considered "pseudonymous": everyone has a copy of literally all transactions that ever happened, but senders and recipients aren't named.

It seems that explaining complex scientific, mathematical or technical concepts grows more difficult by the year. In the past, the "man on the street" could understand many of these, simply by being provided with a good analogy and/or simplified process charts — I did not need to learn fluid dynamics to understand how a steam engine worked. Broadly. But somewhere along the way, it became ever more difficult to find working analogies: Einsteinian spacetime, quantum mechanics, and don't get me started on string theory.

IMO, this video goes a very long way in explaining a concept, while studiously avoiding the rocks most similar attempts crash their ships onto: either with analogies so far removed that they are completely useless, or succumbing to sneaking in some maths in a "Deus ex Machina" black box while explaining to the viewer that it would be best if they looked over there at the birdie.

As a tech person, I think what has been accomplished with crypto is amazing, but as an economist, I see a problem that I never hear discussed in crypto circles.
Investments make terrible currency.
Our currency value needs to be stable and predictable over the long term. When people trade in Bitcoin, more often then not they aren't looking for a stable form of currency, rather they are looking to buy low and sell high. For myself, I might invest in a little VC of one type or another, but I would never accept payment in VC because, among other things, I couldn't be sure the value wouldn't plummet any time after I was paid.

Think of real currencies like a metro pass. Metro passes are the currency of the metro. When I hold a pass the metro is in debt to me. I am owed a ride on a train. The same idea works for theater tickets, arcade tokens, and another token that can be used to purchase something real and tangible. Why would a company redeem these paper and plastic tokens for things of real and tangible value? Societal laws.
What about Government fiat? What is it the promise of? The answer is that anyone who wishes to participate in society and reap the benefits of it has to pay taxes of one form or another. Taxes are enforcible by the state and failure to pay them will result in a loss of currency, property or freedom.
So it's not what fiat is redeemable for, but what it prevents that gives it value. Since we all find ourselves in a similar situation, we trade in fiat.
So again, I ask anyone, what is crypto the promise of? And please, don't tell me "freedom from government oppression" Give me a real tangible answer, because the way I see it, crypto isn't the promise of anything at all. It is the ultimate Ponzi scheme. However it's spread so wide and so far, it may work in perpetuity. There won't be any big crash, rather it will just circulate around creating winners and losers.
There are other substantial problems of replacing government fiat with crypto unless people here believe that crypto will always work alongside government currency.

Good stuff, but the hashing function explanation contains some inaccuracies. By design a hashing function is irreversible. This is not hard to prove since all hashing functions map an infinite domain of inputs to a finite domain of outputs, meaning that for every generated hash value there are an infinite number of possible input messages. Another name for hashing functions is one-way functions hinting at their irreversible natures. Because they're irreversible they can never be used for encryption but they can be used to generate cryptographic signatures. What makes a hashing function suitable for cryptography has to do with properties like resistance to pre-image attacks  and collisions.

Excellent explanation, but it fails to show the pitfalls.  It mentions that fraude is very difficult unless you have 50% of the computing power of all miners, but that doesn't make it impossible.  Let's say I first pay lots of bitcoins buying real life stuff, ex. lots of rigs to do bitcoin mining.  All that is legit (but delivered anonymously so that I remain anonymous even for the people I bought the stuff from), but now I start from a block before all those payments and recalculate all the blocks, but replacing my payments with ones with a lot lower value and I use my rigs to do the work for each of those blocks and ensure I get the longest chain by adding tiny transactions between multiple accounts I (anonymously)  have.  In the end I then would have the longest chain and hence be the reference and in doing so have changed the amount I paid for my huge rigs to peanuts and having taken over the entire block-chain (as other miners will have shorter chains, they have to pick up mine at some point, so I don't have to keep the faking up forever).  As long as the crypto currency is very active, reaching that level of over-poweredness may be impossible, but not if transactions start to drop.  And that's not even touching the big question-marks on exchange rate between the crypto currency and any other currency.  That might hold for any currency, but at least most normal ones are in some sense backed by a country which has some reason for it to behave in a certain way.  With a crypto currency you have no idea who could influence it or have a reason to want to and you don't have a country behind it that could initiate steps to stabilize it.  In short: crypto currencies are pyramid scams run by lots of anonymous bad guys exploiting even more anonymous unaware victims.

Crypto currency. An anatomy of online deception. The originating organization provides an individual that has given it money with a password to an entry on a public ledger that serves as his receipt so that he may view the record of this transaction at any time. This contribution is essentially a gift. Contributions are sought in discrete amounts, such as fifty cents. The password to access the receipt for each of these fifty cent gifts is titled a key and employing a misnomer the record of the amount of the gift is titled a crypto coin.

These are not deposits, the amount may not be withdrawn and the individual is not entitled to a refund. Members of the originating organization may in turn again gift the money that has accrued to them to their own organization in order to issue receipts to themselves and may do this as many times as they wish. No regulations hinder them and it costs them nothing. Crypto is not currency even if a merchant accepts it in barter.

In order to recover part, all or even more than his expenditure the individual may sell the right to view the entry for his transaction that serves as his receipt for the gift that he has made and provides the new purchaser with the key. The new purchaser in turn may likewise sell his right to view this entry to the online ledger to someone else. That is what is being traded. The right (password titled a key) to view a receipt (record of the amount on an online ledger titled a coin), nothing more that in itself is of no intrinsic value.

At its inception crypto currency enabled persons engaged in illicit activity to make payments to each other avoiding government scrutiny. Each dollar entry to the ledger is publicly visible while concealing the name of the individual. Only the individual has the key. If this is lost he cannot bring up his transaction, as the key is not retrievable. Nor can anyone else. The relevance of block chain technology to this scheme is that it prevents hacking as well as discovering who made a particular payment.

The originating organization continues to issue the right to view receipts for contributions, euphemistically titled coins, without anyone actually having sent it money, to the party that correctly guesses the characters by which each receipt is identified. The party to whom the keys are awarded must update the ledger. They are compensated for their mining service by selling their keys.

More money may be squeezed out of the process. Exchanges have been set up in order to facilitate trading of these receipts called coins and to store in a wallet the passwords, called keys. If you lose the password you cannot view the ledger entry that serves as a receipt leaving you with nothing to sell.

That anyone is willing to pay money to view a receipt for which the original holder received nothing defies rational logic. That others purchase this right from them for huge sums of money is even less credible. The system crashes when it runs out of gullible victims to whom the right to view a ledger entry may be sold.


Footnotes:

The above discussion provides a conceptual analysis so that details do not obscure the process. The block chain is a shared public ledger. In practice, an individual installs a crypto wallet on his computer that generates a crypto address and includes a private key with which to sign transactions. Transactions are verified through a process called mining in which a party earns crypto currency.

Example:

Unsavoury character A demands an $11,000 payment from someone of similar ilk, character B that is owed to him for the substance that his courier successfully delivered while eluding authorities.

Financial institutions must report suspicious activity to a law enforcement agency and that will certainly happen in this case, as each has a notorious reputation. They decide to circumvent the likelihood that their effort will raise a red flag by making the transfer using crypto currency.

A offers to sell eleven units of crypto currency that he bought at the time of inception for fifty cents each to B for $11,000.

B agrees to purchase these eleven coins for $1000 each.

A receives the expected $11,000 payment. From whom he does not know or apparently care.

The dollar value of these transactions is displayed in the public ledger without revealing the identities of the parties. B is delightfully surprised when he discovers that another buyer has already purchased seven of these coins so he pays for the remaining four and orders more substance from A.

Naïve bidders observing this exchange snap up some of these coins for themselves under the impression that this is digital gold.

IMO this is a perfect explanation of why Bitcoin has all the features for real money like Gold and why the 21 Million limit makes Bitcoin the ultimate store of value.  We know gold is scarce, but we'll never know how many ounces will ever be mined.  Somebody could hit a pocket of pure Gold the size of Texas and there goes the scarcity argument.  That cannot happen with Bitcoin.  Plus, Bitcoin is easily transported and easily stored which is not true of Gold.  Bitcoin beats all other world currencies in that the purchasing power actually increases over time instead of decreasing like Dollars.  If you put 10 Bitcoin or 10 one dollar bills in your sock drawer 10 years ago which will buy you more today?  That is an excellent store of purchasing power.  If you buy 1 Bitcoin today for $7,500 or put $7,500 one dollar bills in a box under your bed, which do you think will be able to purchase more ten years from now?  I have to believe Bitcoin will continue to increase in purchasing power whereas the dollar will continue to be inflated away.  Also, each Bitcoin can be sub-divided into 100 Million smaller money units called Satoshi after the creator of Bitcoin.  What happens when 1 Satoshi = 1 penny?  It means each whole Bitcoin is worth 1 Million Dollars.  What if 1 Satoshi reaches 1 Dollar?  Then every Bitcoin now has the purchasing power of 100 Million Dollars.  Seeing the past decade track record of Bitcoin why would anybody NOT put a couple hundred dollars into Bitcoin and just sit on it a few years?  You can buy over 1 Million Satoshi for less than $75 right now.  10 Million Satoshi for less than $750 right now.  A lot people piss away that much in pizza and beer.  Why not invest in yourself and your family for a change?  Good luck.

@4:47 your explanation of signature is not quite correct... and a bit confusing. The graphic show that the Alice signature changes from one message to another message is not quite what you showed. Here is correct sequence of event:
1 - Alice use an hash algorithm tool - SHA256 - for example to produce a hash from her message. The hash copy is called "message digest".
2 - Alice then signs the "message digest" with her private key. The result of this is a digital signature. Now keep in mind Alice always uses her private key to sign any "message digest" and there private key never changes. Your animation shows that the signature Alice keeps changing from one message digest to other is quite confusing and technical speaking is not correct. In other words, you short cut the step of how Alice produces the "message digest". No, Alice does not sign a message with her private key. Alice signs the "message digest" with her private key. This is huge difference.

The question I have at the end of the video is this: If Bitcoin is simply a decentralized currency, which is ultimately useless if you cannot exchange this currency for real goods, why would a centralized, ESTABLISHED currency ever assign value to it? Currency value assumes the institution enforcing it will continue to exist enforcing it. Using Bitcoin is essentially a slap to the face to any established centralized currency. The bitcoin user benefits if local available currency is less stable, but adds unnecessary risk+hassle if the local currency IS stable. In fact, using Bitcoin in an economy already distributing a valued currency is actively hedging that the valued currency will eventually fall. Is this the ultimate idea behind using Bitcoin? Investing in the failure of the USD, or the Euro, or whatever local centralized currency you have the choice to use?

Ok Ok Ok wait a sec.....if an input always produces the same hash output, that means there are "rules" being followed somewhere along the line in order to generate that output, and have it be the same each time for a same input. These rules MUST be coded somewhere in the software. Someone MUST have originally came up with the idea and programmed it into existence. If we know the rules, then we could reconstruct an input from a given output. If said output didn't work in reverse (i.e. some derivatives, etc), the whole system wouldn't work because outputs would become essentially random with no correlating input, thus making decryption on the other end impossible (one output could have several possible inputs, with no way to determine which one it really was).

So how is it even possible we don't know what these rules are?!?!?! They have to be written in code somewhere on every single "machine" involved...how has no one found them?

Why is it optional to include transactions in a block? Would that not make it possible for a transaction to just accidentally be left by the wayside? How do the miners know what transactions have been broadcast? Wouldn't leaving a transaction out while someone else includes it in their block create forking blockchains? One fork for each individual way transactions are organized? Or is it that miners know that it has already been included in a block, and therefore everyone computes the others without it? And the overtaking of fradulent chains would then happen, because the others have a different list of ransactions already included and yet to be included. So you can't just leave out a single transaction out of yours, because it would autocorrect on the blockchains of the others.
Wouldn't this also mean that whenever a block is completed, every other miner has to stop working on their block?
So i guess having a big transaction fee would help with having it included sooner or something? Because everyone wants to have the blockchains with the highest transaction fees to them...
But that would mean that if someone right now included a transaction with 0 transaction fees, it would be left by the wayside indefinitely, because everyone else would want to pick better transactions to include.
Unless of course you have less transactions happening than it takes time to mine a block, so you actually can fill up blocks and leaving transactions out wouldn't matter, since it doesn't change the work you need to do and there's still room for more.
But that would make the incentive system meaningless, since everyone includes all the transactions in the block anyway.
And what happens if the number of transactions permanently exceeds 1700 per 10 minutes? Wouldn't that just lead to an infinitely growing backlog of transactions that need to be included in a block?
Both lead to problems, so the only solution is to have often less, but sometimes more transactions per ten minutes, but that can't be guaranteed.
What will happen if bitcoin grows too big, and 1700/10min just doesn't cut it any more? How could a completely decentralized network agree on shorter processing times?

I see many enthusiast including some governments who want to use block chains for a wide array of things including fairly narrow applications such as recording land parcels ownership. However, it is my understanding that a block chain can only be reliable if it's popular enough (i.e. that there is enough mining competition on it to prevent any one agent from editing it). Hence, those applications are unworkable.


I would be grateful if anyone can find a flaw in my reasoning as to why there can only be a select few reliable block chains in the world at any given time.
Or maybe there is a solution to this issue.


The proof of work is a key that the miners are racing to find first. The reliability of the chain depends on the difficulty/impossibility for any one miner to win consistently that race. I'm using "mining power" to mean "computational power devoted to solving blocks".

1. The difficulty of wining the race consistently on one specific chain depends on the total mining power devoted to that chain relative to one miner's available mining power on that chain.
2. The hardware used to mine on one block chain can easily be used for mining on a different block chain.
1&2 means the reliability of the chain depends on pitting the mining power devoted TO IT versus the mining power of any single miner of ANY chain.
That means the number of reliable chains in the world is limited by the share of mining power of the most powerful miner.

If the most powerful miner has 1/5th of the worlds mining power, there can be a maximum of 5 reliable chains.
If the most powerful miner has 1/100th of the worlds mining power, there can be a maximum of 100 reliable chains.


For example: let's rank the block chains in order of mining power devoted to them :
- The 100th+ chains will necessarily have less than 1/100th of the worlds mining power devoted to it.
- If any miner controls 1/100th of the worlds mining power, they can attack (i.e. edit previous blocks) any chain ranked 100th or more

This is a really amazing video about cryptocurrency, and it explained it much better than any other video i could find. however, i got curious about how someone trying to commit fraud could succeed, and wanted to know how a system could deal with this kind of situation:

Here we have 7 entities; Alice, Bob, Charlie, and 4 Miners. All 4 miners have roughly equal computing capabilities. Alice and Bob are not miners and cannot contribute computational work. We'll say Alice and Charlie are secretly two accounts belonging to the same person, although that is not critical to the situation.
Let's say Alice is attempting to commit fraud. Alice is paying Bob $100, and broadcasts that transaction to Bob, and only 2 of the miners. Alice broadcasts a fraudulent transaction, say Alice pays Charlie(Alice's own account) $100, to the other 2 miners.
Now Miners 1 and 2 have a correct block and Miners 3 and 4 have a fraudulent block that they think is accurate. 2 blocks with proof of work will be broadcast, one block with the correct transaction and one block with fraudulent transaction. We now have a fork in the road. The Miners will continue working on their current blockchain. However, since each side (Miners 1+2 and Miners 3+4) both have roughly the same amount of computational power, they can both contribute the same amount of work, and therefore the same amount of blocks. Because of this, no one fork will outpace the other, and both will maintain somewhat equal length.

This is where the confusion, especially for the Miners, sets in. Each fork will have roughly the same amount of blocks, and therefore, no one will know if they were working on the correct fork, or are still working off of the fraudulent transaction. Bob might know which is correct if he was expecting a transaction; he can look through the blocks at the beginning of each fork and determine that the block where he gets paid from Alice is accurate. But even then, since Bob has no computational power, he cannot contribute work to the correct chain in an attempt to prove that is the correct chain. To top it all off, Charlie can even claim he was expecting a transaction from Alice.

So even if Bob picks up what is happening, how will the Miners? How can they settle which fork is correct? All comments are appreciated, I'm just really curious how a cryptocurrency could combat this.

ХАОС ОБРЕЧЕН на ПРОВАЛ, так как управление хаусом это теория.
Если вы Стивен Манн и это не его таст))
Теория «управляемого хаоса» – это современный феномен, геополитическая доктрина, уходящая своими корнями в древнейшие науки, такие как философия, математика, физика. Понятие «хаос» возникло от названия в древнегреческой мифологии изначального состояния мира, некой «разверзшейся бездны», из которой возникли первые божества.

Попытки научного осмысления понятий «порядок» и «хаос» сформировали теории направленного беспорядка, обширные классификации и типологии хаоса. В древнейшей историко-философской традиции хаос понимался как все собой обнимающее и порождающее начало. В античном мировосприятии безвидный и непостижимый хаос наделен формообразующей силой и означал первичное бесформенное состояние материи и первопотенцию мира.

Современный уровень научных исследований обосновал теорию хаоса на утверждении того, что сложные системы чрезвычайно зависимы от первоначальных условий, и небольшие изменения в окружающей среде могут привести к непредсказуемым последствиям.

Автором теории «управления хаосом» является Стивен Манн.

Not much of this made sense. Still trying to figure out how Wozniak was ripped off for $70k worth of crypto.

I had asked someone a bottom-line question: If I have $500,000 worth of crypto, and I want to get cash for it, where do I go? Their answer was that, since there is no centralization, I would have to GO FIND SOMEONE who BOTH has $500,000 AND has the willingness to purchase it.

That does not sound like a very good deal to me.

Someone else has all of the high-powered computers, and someone else has the powers and access. I do not trust others that much. The heists mentioned in the news drive this lack of trust even deeper into the ground.

Not being able to easily, reliably, or quickly cash out crypto is a big weakness, and it points to the bigger weakness of crypto.

It's value is linked to cash money.

One dollar is worth one dollar ONLY because we all agree that one dollar is worth one dollar. From my boss, to the bank, to my landlord, and even to me, one dollar is worth one dollar. Even if it is technically worth $0.87, when we exchange, we all treat it like one dollar.

Since my landlord does not see the value in crypto at all, this makes crypto worthless on an important level. When you have one million worth of crypto, the drinks are on someone who has cash.

When everyone agreed that a chicken was worth one dollar, people paid their debts with chickens. The doctor gets three chickens for making a house call.

The challenge will be to get EVERYONE to agree that one crypto is worth one crypto, and that one crypto is worth one of X, which will have to be equivalent to one dollar WITHOUT REFERENCING that one dollar at all.

So long as one of something is worth one of something, then things are fine. The problem comes in when one of something is suddenly worth ZERO of something. Then, there's a solution that people just aren't seeing.

Quantum-computing vs. blockchain?

14:08
Let me correct you a bit here. The irreversibility of the Hash function results is not due to some computation complexity. It is much sipler in fact.
Just take a look, on the right side you have 256 bits of information.
On the left side you have a text, with no limit to number of characters specified, meaning it contains way more tan 256 bits.
This means that the result is computed by dropping some information out.
And even if you are smart enough to figure out how this information was dropped and you can reconstruct it step by step, there is no way you can find out when you have reconstructed ebough information.

So it's not like you can't reverse engeneer a hash function and get a result by feeding it some hash string, but you will end up with an infinite amoubt of possible results with no way of knowing which one is correct.

EDIT: oh, and don't forget that the information shredding can easily be done in such a way so you don't know if the shredded bit was 1 or 0.
In this case the number of possible "correct" reconstructed strings you get by reverse hashing go from infinity up to "2 to the power of infinity" which is... you know...

So there are a couple things I didn't quite grab here. First is fees.
So a miner decided what transactions are on the block it's working on, so most will just add the top 2,400 transactions with the highest fees. Alright.
But where are the transactions stores in the meantime? Not a "Block" in the blockchain, I presume? Is there a bit of data in between the blocks, with all the new transactions waiting to be put in a block?
Assuming there are more than 2400 transactions per block with fees, and this continues for years, all the transactions that haven't made the cut yet must be held somewhere, right?

Secondly, I feel that per transaction verification was just glossed over. A miner will take the 2,400 transactions it thinks it wants, checks the hash on each to make sure it's legit, if so adds it to it's desired block and starts chipping away at it. Everyone's mining their own version of the block, presumably with "Pay 12.5 coins to me" and the most fees in it. Cool.
But once a block is mined, and added to the blockchain, how do the other miners know if it's safe to keep mining based off this block? How do they know it doesn't have bad transactions in it?

Do they go "Well, let's check the transactions in there, ah, this one's bad, must be a fake block, I'll ignore it and keep mining"?
Thus all the "good" miners keep only bothering with the good chain, and an "evil" miner group would have to keep toe to toe with them forever to keep up?

So, all this proof of work isn't checking how legit the transactions are, it's just saying "I checked them, they're all cool"? Literally proof of your work.

I'd ask why not just have the users run checks on the transactions themselves then, but "mining" is just a way to sync the blockchains, not verify transactions, as transaction verification is just a simple hash check anyone can do.
(I do assume both the signature and public key are published with each transaction, yes?)
But that'd be so laborious that we use mining to perform both tasks.

How about balances? When do we check if someone actually has the balance to send you something? Is this more work for the miners, in the pre-block stage? Check not only that the transaction's signature is valid, but that the sender had the available funds to do so?
Are they going back through the entire history to check this, or, at the end of every transaction, do they just write a little "Now alice has 0.21 bitcoins available", so you only need to check the last block they sent or received something with?

You missed the most important point.

The technology of blockchains looks mostly OK. That is interesting, but not the most important part.

Bitcoin is not money. Money is a social, not technological construct. A Bitcoin is at base a number, with no intrinsic value. Using "coin" in the name does not make currency or money. All the current "cryptocurrencies" are not currencies. (Or at least not any more than Pizza-parlor game tokens.)

This encrypted and validated exchange of tokens is interesting, and should find use, but they are not more than speculative value.

Without government backing, "cryptocurrencies" have no anchor for value, and are neither currency or money.

Using "coin" or "cash" in the name is not enough.

How about this to increase scalability:
Divide users into a few groups. Each group keeps its own blockchain. If you transfer to someone inside the group, it works as it always does. If you transfer to someone outside the group, that gets added to a running sum and is written into the local blockchain. After a block is completed, this running sum is sent off to an intergroup blockchain that does the same thing, but seeing the groups as users. After one of those blocks complete, the intergroup transactions are added to the destination group's chain.
Everyone only needs their local chain and the intergroup chain. This way you won't need a server and high speed connection to store the blockchain if bicoin is used as much as visa.

They claim that the app will use very little bandwidth so will be cheap for the user to mine and won’t require any technical ability. Gaming (gambling market) Many gaming companies now accept bitcoin as a form of payment. The problem is many people find bitcoin complicated and hard to purchase. Electroneum state that their new currency will help to solve this problem by allowing users to mine coins from their mobile phone which could then be used for gaming. Winnings can then be paid back to the users wallet.

The team decide to start developing a crypto currency that improves on what is currently available.
Mining pool software: To make mining easier, with open source so that others can develop their own pool. Blockchain explorer: Used to verify payments on the blockchain. Third party API: So that third parties can accept the currency as payment. Why should you invest? Electroneum state that their new currency will be much easier to use than those currently on the market and aim to appeal more to the mass market.

The team behind the currency have a history of founding successful companies and are already a properly registered British company. Duncan Logal, he CEO of Rocketspace who helped huge companies such as Uber and Spotify has also publicly tweeted that this will be the first ICO that he’s investing in. Roadmap The official roadmap will depend on the amount of funds that is raised but they say that the general roadmap will be as follows: Global translations of the app. Integration of a global SMS system authenticate users and make the transfer of coins even easier. International promotion of the new platform. Development of a GUI CPU miner that is capable of running in Windows and a more accessible GUI wallet for Windows. They’ll be building a virtual currency exchange app.

Conclusion They have a solid team behind them with a great track record. The high token supply may be an issue for some but their point on making crypto payments similar to FIAT with a 2 decimal point system does make sense.

There is a thing called a Rainbow list that has a list of possible messages that match a certain hashed output.  In short if the hash look like 2x1034e, there are a finite smaller set of possible messages that would match that.  That being said, the longer the message that was hashed was, the more unlikely the Rainbow table for that particular hash would include the unique message.  This is why it is much more difficult to guess longer, more complex passwords because even if you have a shorter list of possibles (relative to the total list of possibles), the chances you have THE right password, you have to test all possbiles that match.

Let me see if I can take a whack at the problems quantum computation adds to cryptocurrency without F'ing it up.

So, specifically, undoing SHA256:

Lets say I start with 256 qbits, not practical right now, but emphasis on the "right now". I start with these qbits entangled with another set of 256 qbits and each in a 50/50 superposition of whatever counts for a 1 or a 0.

Its not the same process, but a theoretically similar algorithm with extra "quantumness" is applied to one set of qbits resulting in an output that equally represents every single possible SHA256 output hash (redundant, I know, but so is my pointing it out).

Now for the magic of quantum computing, where by "magic" I mean "certainty" and by "computing" I mean "magic". I force the resultant superimposed, hashed qbits into a defined state, specifically, the state of the SHA256 hash I want to undo.

Automatically, by the scary power of quantum voodoo, the entangled set of qbits that were paired with the now hashed qbits have taken on a state trivially convertable to the necessary input to give that specific SHA256 output.

If I'm not mistaken, this uh.. breaks.. well.. everything that relies on SHA256. You could literally recompute the entire block-chain faster than you could download it.

Now, as to theoreticals, if I successfully made a quantum computer like this, the absolute last thing I would want anyone to know is that I had made a quantum computer like this. So, assuming my logic isn't seriously flawed, by the time Bitcoin is found out to be broken, it will have aleady been broken for quite some time, and there will be perfectly and absolutely no way to fix it.

Anyone else concerned?

Just a minor nitpick. If you have a 1 in x chance of getting something per attempt, then that doesn't imply that on average it takes x attempts to get that thing. Just that every x attempts will yield 1 success. When a bitcoin miner attempts to find the right number, and if they have a 1 in a billion chance of getting it, then it will on average take them around 700 million attempts.

+3Blue1Brown
Quite a good video, but you make a major mathematical blunder, when stating that nobody has found a way yet to calculate the pre-image from the hash. It's not that nobody has found a way yet, its because it is impossible. The reason is, that there is no 1-to-1 relationship between the elements of the set of inputs (pre-images) and the set of output (hashes) of the cryptographic hash function, or in other words: It's because a hash function is never bijective. This means that information is lost during the transformation, which prevents the reversal.
To clarify with an example: The SHA-256 function has a hash of 256-bit for all inputs, this means that there are overall just 2^256 hashes which is roughly 1.16*10^77. That's all there is and can be.
Now lets take a simple passphrase made up of 35 ASCII characters. Such a message length alone carries 256^35 or roughly 1.94*10^84 bits. And you can insert input of any length into SHA-256, not just 35 characters. The set of pre-images is thus practically infinite, while the set of hashes is limited to 1.16*10^77 elements. Thus information loss occurs, which can not be reverse (retrieving information from nothing doesn't work). It's thus not because nobody has yet found a way, but because it's impossible to reverse a hash function due to loss of information.

There are a few important concepts that I am constantly needing to clarify for people, and which I therefore wish you had covered in this video.

1. If you only "count the leading zeros" in the target hash, then you can only double (or halve) the difficulty. Bitcoin instead uses a target value. The hash simply needs to be less than the target value.

2. Guessing random numbers (and your video representation) when trying to complete the proof-of-work leads many people to think that all the miners are working on IDENTICAL blocks, this makes it seem like the miner that can work the fastest will ALWAYS get the block. It also doesn't cover what happens when all the possible numbers have been tried without a solution.

3. While it can be figured out with a bit of critical thinking, I didn't see anything explaining why a miner can't just give themselves an arbitrarily larger reward in the block they create.

4. There is nothing explaining how the users or miners know what each person's public key is. Your ledger example implies that the ledger "pays Alice" and that I can use Alice's pk to verify that Alice signed it, but how are all those pk shared with EVERYONE?

5. It would have been nice if the video could have included a bit more detail about how transactions are built and how they work. At least something showing how they consist of two lists (inputs and outputs).
